case_name: Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai's daughter v. Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai's son

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1251 of 1967 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1251 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 29, 1966 of Madras High Court in S.A. No. 167 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 29, 1966 of the Madras High Court in S.A. No. 167 of 1963.

facts.text: Appellant is daughter of Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the daughter of one Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai, who died on 17th January, 1949, by one of his wives,

facts.text: Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai died on 17th January 1949.

anchor.surface_text: who died on 17th January, 1949, by one of his wives, the second respondent. The first respondent is his son by another wife.

facts.text: Appellant is daughter by second respondent, one of Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai's wives.

anchor.surface_text: by one of his wives, the second respondent. The first respondent is his son by another wife. The parties belong to the

facts.text: First respondent is son of Ayyappan Mathevan Pillai by another wife.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent is his son by another wife. The parties belong to the Krishnanvaka Community found mainly in the

facts.text: Parties belong to Krishnanvaka Community in Kanyakumari district of Tamil Nadu.

anchor.surface_text: The parties belong to the Krishnanvaka Community found mainly in the Kanyakumari district of Tamil Nadu. During the appellants

facts.text: During appellant's minority, her mother and first respondent entered into deed of partition giving appellant 9 out of 79 items of father's property.

anchor.surface_text: During the appellants minority her mother and the first respondent entered into a deed of partition under which the appellant was given 9 out of 79 items belonging to her father.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit for partition and possession of half share in all father's properties.

anchor.surface_text: She filed the suit out of which this appeal arises for partition and possession of a half share in all her fathers properties.

facts.text: Appellant's claim based on custom of special pathnibhagam where daughter entitled to share on basis of mothers, entitling her to half share.

anchor.surface_text: Her claim was based on the allegation that in the companymunity to which the parties belong there was a custom of a special kind of pathnibhagam. While under the ordinary pathnibhagam a mans sons by different wives get their shares on the basis that whatever their number the property is divided according to the number of wives he had, rather than, on a per capita basis, the special kind of pathnibhagam pleaded by the plaintiff was that even a daughter was entitled to share on the same basis.

facts.text: Learned Subordinate Judge held against plaintiff after considering evidence and earlier decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge who tried the suit, on a company- sideration of the evidence in the case, as also various earlier ,,decisions regarding this custom held against the plaintiff.

facts.text: District Judge of Kanyakumari allowed appeal based on earlier decisions without going into evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Oil appeal the District Judge of Kanyakumari without going into the evidence but on the basis of some earlier decisions allowed the appeal.

facts.text: Madras High Court Single Judge in Second Appeal held special custom not established by decisions relied on by District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In the Second Appeal before the High Court the learned Single Judge took the view that the decisions relied on by the District Judge cannot be said to have established the existence of the special custom pleaded by the plaintiff.

facts.text: First defendant sought to sustain partition deed as family arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st defendant also sought to sustain the partition deed on the basis that it was the result of a family arrangement.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds custom of pathnibhagam established in community but special kind extending to daughters not established.

anchor.surface_text: Thus while the existence of the custom of pathnibhagam in the companymunity may be said to have been established, the special kind of pathnibhagam pleaded by the plaintiff cannot be said to have been established

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs of first respondent to be paid by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In this view it is unnecessary to go into the question of family arrangement. The appeal is dismissed with companyts of the 1st respondent to be paid by the appellant.

facts.text: Avikutti Bhagavathi ANR. v. Chithambarathanu Mathevan decision in 1890 reported in 8 T.L.R. 51 recognized pathnibhagam in Krishnavakakkar.

facts.text: Ramaswami Sadasivan v. Thanu Gouri decision in 1904 held pathni bhagom and observed special extension to daughters.

anchor.surface_text: The next decision is of the year 1904, in Ramaswami Sadasivan v. Thanu Gouri, reported in Kolappa Pillais unreported important cases p. 179. Here again on a Consideration of the evidence it was held that the preponderance of evidence as a whole was in favour of Pathni Bhagom.

facts.text: District Court of Nagercoil S. No. 109 of 1096 M.B. dated 22nd December 1923 referred to special pathnibhagam.

anchor.surface_text: She pleaded that as Mathevan Pillai had two wives and she was the daughter by one wife and the 1st defendant the son by the other wife each of them was entitled to a half share.

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle from Privy Council in Collector of Madura case.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position regarding the place of customary law among the Hindus is well established. In The Collector of Madura Moottoo Ramalinga Sethupathy 1  it was observed by the Privy Council Under the Hindu system of law clear proof of usage will outweigh the written text of the law. In Rama Rao v. Rajah of Pittapur   2   the Privy Council observed When a custom or usage, whether in regard to a tenure or a contract or a family right, is repeatedly brought to the notice of the Courts of a country, the Courts may hold that custom or usage to be introduced into the law without the necessity of proof in each individual case.

concepts.interpretation: Custom repeatedly recognized and affirmed in series of decisions based on evidence becomes incorporated in general law; proof unnecessary, shifts onus.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: legal position regarding the place of customary law among the Hindus is number well established. In The Collector of Madura Moottoo Ramalinga Sethupa

concepts.unlisted_description: Custom becomes law without further proof if established through multiple court decisions based on evidence (Rama Rao, Premraj, Ujagar Singh).

precedents.citation: The Collector of Madura Moottoo Ramalinga Sethupathy 1

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Madura Moottoo Ramalinga Sethupathy 1 it was observed by the Privy Council Under the Hindu system of law clear proof of usage will outweigh the written text of the law.

precedents.case_name: The Collector of Madura v. Moottoo Ramalinga Sethupathy
precedents.cited_proposition: Clear proof of usage outweighs the written text of Hindu law
precedents.cited_holding: Under the Hindu system of law clear proof of usage will outweigh the written text of the law.

precedents.citation: Rama Rao v. Rajah of Pittapur 2

anchor.surface_text: Rama Rao v. Rajah of Pittapur 2 the Privy Council observed When a custom or usage, whether in regard to a tenure or a contract or a family right, is repeatedly brought to the notice of the Courts of a country, the Courts may hold that custom or usage to be introduced into the law without the necessity of proof in each individual case.

precedents.case_name: Rama Rao v. Rajah of Pittapur
precedents.cited_proposition: Custom repeatedly recognized by courts becomes part of law without further proof
precedents.cited_holding: When a custom or usage... is repeatedly brought to the notice of the Courts of a country, the Courts may hold that custom or usage to be introduced into the law without the necessity of proof in each individual case.

anchor.surface_text: Premraj v. Chand Kanwar 3 the Privy Council observed It is not doubtful that the ordinary rule is that a party relying on a custom which is at variance with the ordinary Hindu law must allege and prove it. But it is equally beyond doubt that a custom which has been recognised and affirmed in a series of decisions, each of them based on evidence adduced in the particular case, may become incorporated in the general law

precedents.cited_proposition: Custom affirmed in series of decisions based on evidence shifts onus of proof
precedents.cited_holding: a custom which has been recognised and affirmed in a series of decisions, each of them based on evidence adduced in the particular case. may become incorporated in the general law, with the result that the onus of proof no longer lies on those who assert it but upon those who assert an exception to it.

anchor.surface_text: Ujagar Singh v. Mst. Jeo 4 wherein after referring to the statement of law in Rama Rao v. Rajah of Pittapur, earlier referred to, this Court pointed out that when a custom has been so recognised by the courts, it passes into the law of the land and the proof of it then becomes unnecessary under s. 57 1 of the Evidence Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Custom recognized by courts passes into law of the land; proof unnecessary under Evidence Act
precedents.cited_holding: when a custom has been so recognised by the courts, it passes into the law of the land and the proof of it then becomes unnecessary under s. 57 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Palaniappa Chettiar v. Alagan Chetti 1 the Privy Council referred to the statement of law by Mayne in his Hindu Law Edn. 7 , para. 473 to the following effect In some families, however, a custom called patnibhaga prevails of dividing according to mothers...

precedents.cited_proposition: Prevalence of patnibhaga custom in some families and parts of Southern India

precedents.citation: Avikutti Bhagavathi ANR. v. Chithambarathanu Mathevan, reported in 8 T.L.R. 51

anchor.surface_text: Avikutti Bhagavathi ANR. v. Chithambarathanu Mathevan, reported in 8 T.L.R. 51 where the effect of the evidence was stated as follows From the evidence on both sides, it is clear to us that Krishnavakakkar to which the parties belong, follow the Hindu law with one or two points of divergence from it, viz. the widow cohabiting with the brother of her deceased husband and the existence of Pathni Bhagam.

precedents.cited_holding: From the evidence on both sides, it is clear to us that Krishnavakakkar to which the parties belong, follow the Hindu law with one or two points of divergence from it, viz. ... the existence of Pathni Bhagam.

precedents.citation: Ramaswami Sadasivan v. Thanu Gouri, reported in Kolappa Pillais unreported important cases p. 179

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami Sadasivan v. Thanu Gouri, reported in Kolappa Pillais unreported important cases p. 179. Here again on a Consideration of the evidence it was held that the preponderance of evidence as a whole was in favour of Pathni Bhagom. But one of the learned Justice observed The Pathni Bhagon which prevails in this community seems to go even beyond the usual custom known as Pathni Bhagom.

precedents.cited_proposition: Special pathnibhagam where daughters take half share per stirpes even without brothers from same mother
precedents.cited_holding: the Pathni Bhagon which prevails in this community seems to go even beyond the usual custom known as Pathni Bhagom. that it is not only sons of different mothers that take per stirpes according to the number of mothers but when one mother has got only female issue and another a male issue the female issue get a half share in their fathers properties

precedents.citation: Nagaru Pillai Saraswathi Amma v. Thanu Pillai Thanu Pillai, reported in 1944 T.L.R. 710

No. 109 of 1096 M.B., dated 22nd December. 1923, marked Ex A-6 wherein it was observed But it has been held in Kolappa Pillay, page 179 that in the community Krishnavakakars to which the parties belong that when a man dies leaving two wives even though one wife might have only female issues such females issue are entitled to a half share

precedents.case_name: District Court of Nagercoil S. No. 109 of 1096 M.B.
precedents.cited_proposition: Female issues entitled to half share under pathnibhagam in Krishnavakakars
precedents.cited_holding: when a man dies leaving two wives even though one wife might have only female issues such females issue are entitled to a half share as the Pathnibhagam to their mother.

precedents.cited_holding: this community follows the system known as Patnibhagam under which property of the deceased is inherited according to the number of widows he had irrespective of the existence of the children to the deceased.
